case_name: Subsidiary of Imperial Chemical Industries Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1308 of 1970 filed by special leave from Calcutta High Court order.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court order dated September 8, 1970 in Income Tax Reference No. 50 of 1971.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the order dated September 8. 1970 of the Calcutta High Court in Income Tax Reference No. 50 of 1971. A. Palkhivala, Veda

facts.text: Assessment year 1962-63 for the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: Tribunal in the matter of assessment of the appellant which was the assessee in respect of the assessment year 1962-63. The Appellate Tribunal had rejected

facts.text: Assessee is 100% subsidiary of Imperial Chemical Industries Ltd., UK (I.C.I.).

anchor.surface_text: The assessee is a 100 subsidiary of Imperial Chemical In- dustries Ltd., incorporated in the United Kingdom  hereinafter referred to as I.C.I.

facts.text: I.C.I. advanced large amounts by way of loans to the assessee from time to time.

anchor.surface_text: I.C.I. advanced large amounts by way of loans to the assessee from time to time. This, it was claimed, was done for subscribing to shares in three Indian

facts.text: Loans for subscribing to shares in Indian Explosives Ltd. (I.E.L.), Alkalai Chemical Corporation of India (A.C.C.I.) and Atic Industries Private Ltd. (ATIC).

anchor.surface_text: This, it was claimed, was done for subscribing to shares in three Indian Companies called Indian Explosives Ltd., Alkalai Chemical Corporation of India and Atic

facts.text: Assessee transferred the shares at par to I.C.I. in satisfaction of the loans.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently the assessee transferred the shares in the aforesaid companypanies at par to I.C.I. in satisfaction of the loans advanced by that companypany.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer assessed assessee to capital gains under Section 52 of the Income-tax Act, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer applied S. 52 of the Income-tax Act, 1961  hereinafter called the Act  and assessed the assessee to capital gains.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner held assessee not liable to capital gains under Section 52.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner took the companytrary view and held that on the facts which had been established, the assessee was number liable to capital

facts.text: Tribunal upheld the decision of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal upheld the decision of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner by a detailed and well reasoned order.

facts.text: Scheme conceived prior to 30th November 1956 when Finance Bill reimposed capital gains tax.

anchor.surface_text: The entire scheme was companyceived and was put into operation prior to 30th November 1956 when the Finance Bill was introduced reimposing capital gains tax

facts.text: Transfers of shares made in March-April 1961 after RBI approval in February 1961.

anchor.surface_text: The approval of the Reserve Bank to these transfers was received in February 1961 and the transfers were made in March April 1961.

facts.text: I.C.I. called upon assessee in February 1961 to transfer shares due to change in Indian taxation by Finance Act 1959.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances, it was decided by I.C.I. that the investments in the three companypanies should he held by it directly. For that reason it called

facts.text: Negotiations with Government of India in October 1953 for I.E.L.

anchor.surface_text: Negotiations advanced more towards October 1953 when the representatives of I.C.I. met the officials of the Government of India.

facts.text: Declaration of Intention dated November 5, 1953 for I.E.L.

anchor.surface_text: In the final draft of the Declaration of Intention dated November 5. 1953, it was mentioned that the Government had agreed that if T.C.I.

facts.text: Assessee applied to RBI on 21st December 1954 for borrowing Rs. 160 lakhs from I.C.I. for I.E.L. shares.

anchor.surface_text: On 21st December 1954, the assessee applied to the Reserve Bank of India for formal sanction for borrowing Rs. 160 lakhs from I.C.I.

facts.text: Loans advanced from 30th September 1954 to 30th June 1957 equivalent to Rs. 160 lakhs.

anchor.surface_text: The loans were advanced from 30th September 1954 to 30th June 1957 by the I.C.I. to the assessee of the equivalent of Rs. 160 lakhs in Sterling.

facts.text: Rights issue by I.E.L. in 1958, additional loan of Rs. 80 lakhs.

anchor.surface_text: In 1958 there was a Rights Issue by I.E.L. I.C.I. agreed to give a loan of Rs. 80 lakhs to the assessee to companyer the Sterling requirement

facts.text: Assessee called upon by I.C.I. on 15-2-1961 to transfer I.E.L. investments.

anchor.surface_text: On 15-2-1961 the assessee was called upon by I.C.I. to transfer the investments in satisfaction of the loans.

facts.text: Scheme for A.C.C.I. proposed by assessee letter dated 13-12-1955.

facts.text: I.C.I. agreed to advance Rs. 25 lakhs loan to assessee for ATIC on 29-12-1955.

anchor.surface_text: ATIC, the third Company was incorporated primarily for the manufacture of certain Dye-stuffs. On 29-12-1955 I.C.I. agreed to advance Rs. 25 lakhs

The Income-tax Officer applied S. 52 of the Income-tax Act, 1961  hereinafter called the Act  and assessed the assessee to capital gains.

concepts.interpretation: Applied by ITO to assess capital gains but held inapplicable by AAC and Tribunal as no object of tax avoidance; requires connection, reason to believe avoidance under s.45, then FMV.

concepts.unlisted_description: Anti-avoidance provision for understatement of consideration in transfers to connected persons.

anchor.surface_text: Section 52 is in the following terms Consideration for transfer in cases of under- statement Where the person who acquires a capital asset from an assessee is directly or indirectly connected with the assessee and the Income-tax Officer has reason to believe that the transfer was effected with the object of avoidance or reduction of the liability of the assessee under s. 45, the full value of the consideration for the transfer shall, with the previous approval of the Inspecting Asstt. Commissioner, be taken to be the fair market value of the capital asset on the date of the transfer.

concepts.interpretation: Necessary ingredients: (i) direct/indirect connection, (ii) ITO reason to believe object avoidance/reduction of s.45 liability, (iii) then FMV as consideration. Second requires material showing object was tax avoidance.

holdings.text: Section 52 requires: (i) direct/indirect connection between transferee and assessee, (ii) ITO reason to believe (on material) transfer effected to avoid/reduce s.45 liability, (iii) then consideration taken as FMV.

anchor.surface_text: Section 52 is in the following terms Consideration for transfer in cases of under- statement Where the person who acquires a capital asset from an assessee is directly or indirectly connected with the assessee and the Income-tax Officer has reason to believe that the transfer was effected with the object of avoidance or reduction of the liability of the assessee under s. 45, the full value of the consideration for the transfer shall, with the previous approval of the Inspecting Asstt. Commissioner, be taken to be the fair market value of the capital asset on the date of the transfer.

precedents.citation: Sree Meenakshi Mills Ltd. v., Commissioner of Income tax, Madras 31 I.T.R. 28

anchor.surface_text: Sree Meenakshi Mills Ltd. v., Commissioner of Income tax, Madras 1 . In that case it was held that there was noquestion of construction of any statutory provision or document of title. The issues which arose for determination,

precedents.case_name: Sree Meenakshi Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income tax, Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: a finding on a question of fact is open to attack as erroneous in law when there is no evidence to support it or if it is perverse. Where, however, the finding is one of fact, the fact that it is an inference from other basic facts will not alter its character as one of fact; there was no question of construction of any statutory provision or document of title; the issues were questions of fact; findings supported by evidence mean no question of law for reference under s. 66(1)
precedents.cited_holding: The findings of the Tribunal were amply supported by evidence and were eminently reasonable. It, therefore, followed that there was no question which could be referred to the Court under s. 66(1) of the Income tax Act 1922.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeal is allowed and the order of the High Court is hereby set aside. The assessee shall be entitled to its costs in this Court.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; order of the High Court set aside

anchor.surface_text: Section 52 is in the following terms Consideration for transfer in cases of under- statement Where the person who acquires a capital asset from an assessee is directly or indirectly connected with the assessee and the Income-tax Officer has reason to believe that the transfer was effected with the object of avoidance or reduction of the liability of the assessee under s. 45, the full value of the consideration for the transfer shall, with the previous approval of the Inspecting Asstt. Commissioner, be taken to be the fair market value of the capital asset on the date of the transfer.
In the result the appeal is allowed and the order of the High Court is hereby set aside. The assessee shall be entitled to its costs in this Court.
